content.text: Pour approximately \(80 \text{cm}^3\) of water from the beaker into the measuring cylinder. Record the volume \(V_1\) of water
Lower the test-tube, closed end first, into the water in the measuring cylinder and push it down until it is filled with water, as shown in Fig. 1.2. Record the new water level \(V_2\)
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{G}}\) of the glass of the test-tube using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{G}} = (V_{2} - V_{1})\)
Pour approximately \(70 \text{cm}^3\) of water from the beaker into the measuring cylinder. Record the volume \(V_3\) of water

Gently put the test-tube, open end first, into the water in the measuring cylinder and carefully push it down with your finger or pencil until it is just covered with water, as shown in Fig. 1.3. Record the new water level \(V_4\)
Calculate the increase in water level \((V_{4} - V_{3})\)
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) of air in the test-tube using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{A}} = (V_{4} - V_{3}) - V_{\mathrm{G}}\)
Remove the test-tube from the measuring cylinder and pour the water from the tube and the measuring cylinder into the beaker

Remove the test-tube from the measuring cylinder and pour the water from the measuring cylinder into the beaker. Fill the test-tube to the top with water from the beaker. Pour the water from the test-tube into the measuring cylinder. Record the volume \(V_{\mathrm{W}}\) of water from the tube

The aim of this experiment is to determine the internal volume of the test-tube by two methods. The two values are \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) (obtained from parts **(a)** and **(b)**) and \(V_{\mathrm{W}}\) (obtained from part **(c)**). The values obtained from your readings may not be the same

Assuming that the experiments have been carried out correctly and carefully, and that the measuring cylinder scale is accurate, suggest two reasons why the value \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) may be inaccurate and two reasons why the value \(V_{\mathrm{W}}\) may be inaccurate
<label>V<sub>A</sub>:
reason 1
reason 2
<label>V<sub>W</sub>:
reason 1
reason 2
[Total: 10]
The aim of this experiment is to determine the internal volume of a test-tube using displacement methods
Carry out the following instructions referring to Figs. 1.1, 1.2 and 1.3. You are supplied with a beaker of water
Record the value of room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer

Place the thermometer so that its bulb is a horizontal distance \(d = 100 \text{mm}\) from the surface of the lamp, as shown in Fig. 2.1. Record in Table 2.1 the distance \(d\) between the thermometer bulb and the surface of the lamp. Also record the temperature \(\theta\) shown on the thermometer
Move the thermometer so that its bulb is a distance \(d = 80 \text{mm}\) from the surface of the lamp
In the table, record the distance \(d\) and the temperature \(\theta\)
Repeat the steps described in (b)(ii), but using values of \(d\) of \(60 \text{mm}\), \(40 \text{mm}\), \(20 \text{mm}\) and \(10 \text{mm}\)
Switch on the lamp. Leave the lamp switched on until you have completed all the readings

Place the thermometer so that its bulb is a vertical distance \(d_{\mathrm{V}} = 100 \mathrm{mm}\) from the top surface of the lamp, as shown in Fig. 2.2. Use the \(100 \mathrm{mm}\) rod provided to obtain the correct distance. Record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{V}}\) shown on the thermometer

Calculate the difference between \(\theta_{\mathrm{V}}\) and the thermometer reading \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) at a horizontal distance of \(100\mathrm{mm}\) from the lamp. State whether \(\theta_{\mathrm{V}}\) is higher, lower or the same as \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{V}}\) is .........
Move the thermometer away from the lamp and wait for about a minute thermometer to cool

A student suggests that \(\theta_{\mathrm{V}}\) will be higher than the thermometer reading \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) because thermal energy will travel by infra-red radiation and convection to the thermometer bulb above the lamp but by infra-red radiation only when the bulb is to one side of the lamp

If the experiment were to be repeated in order to investigate this suggestion, it would be important to control the conditions. Suggest two such conditions, relevant to this investigation, that should be controlled
Briefly describe a precaution that you took in this experiment in order to obtain a reliable result
[Total: 10]
In this experiment, you will investigate the heating of a thermometer bulb
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Figs. 2.1 and 2.2

You are provided with a lamp and a rule. Do not move the lamp or the rule. During the experiment, you will read temperature values from the thermometer. You should use the card provided to shield your eyes from the direct rays of the lamp

Place the sliding contact \(\mathbf{C}\) on the resistance wire at a distance \(d = 30.0 \text{cm}\) from point \(\mathbf{A}\). Switch on. Measure and record in Table 3.1 the current \(I\) in the circuit and the p.d. \(V\) across the resistor \(\mathbf{R}\). Switch off
Repeat the procedure in step (i) using \(d\) values of \(40.0 \text{cm}\), \(50.0 \text{cm}\), \(70.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\)
Complete the column headings in the table
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(I / A\) (\(x\)-axis)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
The gradient \(G\) of the graph is numerically equal to the resistance \(R\) of the resistor \(\mathbf{R}\)
Write a value for the resistance \(R\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
[Total: 10]
In this experiment, you will determine the resistance of a resistor in a circuit
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 3.1. The circuit is set up for you
Place the screen at a distance \(d = 0.800 \text{m}\) from the illuminated object

Place the lens between the object and the screen and close to the object. Move the lens towards the screen until an enlarged image is formed on the screen. Adjust the position of the lens until the image is as clearly focused as possible
Measure and record the distance \(x\) between the centre of the lens and the screen
Without moving the illuminated object or the screen, move the lens towards the screen until a clearly focused **diminished** image is formed on the screen
Measure and record the distance \(y\) between the centre of the lens and the screen
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens using the equation \(f = \frac{xy}{d}\)
Turn the lens through an angle of \(180^{\circ}\) so that the other side of the lens facing the screen. Repeat steps (a) to (f)
Briefly describe a precaution that you took in this experiment in order to obtain a reliable result
[Total: 10]
A student suggests that the two values of the focal length \(f\) should be the same. State whether or not your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification
In this experiment, you will determine the focal length of a lens
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 4.1
